description:
Malaclemys terrapin pileata, commonly known as the Pileated Diamondback Terrapin, is a subspecies of the Diamondback Terrapin (Malaclemys terrapin) that is found in the coastal regions of the southeastern United States.

This turtle is characterized by a high-domed carapace (upper shell) that is typically dark gray or black in color, with distinct diamond-shaped patterns. The plastron (lower shell) is often yellowish or tan in color. The head and limbs are also dark in color, with distinct patterns of light-colored lines or spots.

Pileated Diamondback Terrapins are adapted to live in brackish and saltwater habitats, including marshes, estuaries, and tidal creeks. They feed primarily on a variety of small crustaceans, mollusks, and aquatic plants. These turtles are known for their ability to tolerate a wide range of salinities and temperatures, allowing them to thrive in the dynamic coastal environments they inhabit.

Conservation efforts are in place to protect this subspecies, as their populations have been impacted by factors such as habitat loss, bycatch in commercial fisheries, and collection for the pet trade. Understanding the ecology and biology of the Pileated Diamondback Terrapin is crucial for developing effective management strategies to ensure the long-term survival of this unique coastal reptile.
